projects.name: Scribblz - Window Drawing Robot
projects.description: An autonomous suction-based robot that creates artwork on vertical glass surfaces. Scribblz uses vacuum suction cups to adhere to windows while a precision pen mechanism draws user-uploaded images.
projects.challenge: Design a robot capable of reliably adhering to smooth vertical surfaces while maintaining precise 2D motion control for drawing. The system needed to handle varying glass conditions, support continuous drawing without losing suction, and convert digital images into smooth pen strokes.
projects.solution: Developed a dual-suction system with redundant vacuum pumps ensuring continuous adhesion. Implemented a CoreXY-style motion system for the pen mechanism, achieving ±0.5mm positioning accuracy. Created custom G-code generation software that converts images to optimized drawing paths with adjustable detail levels.
projects.impact: Successfully demonstrated autonomous window art creation at Olin College expo. The robot drew a 12"x12" portrait in under 45 minutes. Open-sourced the image-to-path conversion algorithm, which has been adopted by 3 other maker projects.

subsystems.name: Vacuum Suction System
subsystems.description: Dual vacuum pump system with 4 suction cups providing 50N of holding force. Includes pressure sensors for adhesion monitoring.

children.name: Vacuum Pumps
children.description: Dual micro diaphragm pumps providing -60kPa vacuum

children.name: Suction Cup Array
children.description: 4x silicone suction cups with quick-release valves

subsystems.name: CoreXY Motion System
subsystems.description: Belt-driven CoreXY gantry providing 200mm x 200mm drawing area with high speed and accuracy.

children.name: NEMA 17 Steppers
children.description: Dual NEMA 17 stepper motors in CoreXY configuration

children.name: GT2 Belt System
children.description: GT2 timing belts with tensioning system

subsystems.name: Pen Lift Mechanism
subsystems.description: Servo-actuated pen holder with adjustable pressure and quick-change pen mount.

subsystems.name: Control Electronics
subsystems.description: Arduino Mega with custom shield, stepper drivers, and sensor interfaces.

milestones.name: Concept Development
milestones.description: Initial concept sketches and feasibility analysis for window-climbing robot

milestones.name: Suction System Prototype
milestones.description: Built and tested vacuum suction system on various glass surfaces

milestones.name: Motion System Integration
milestones.description: Integrated CoreXY motion with suction base, achieved target accuracy

milestones.name: Drawing Software Development
milestones.description: Developed image-to-gcode converter and Arduino firmware

milestones.name: Expo Demonstration
milestones.description: Successfully demonstrated autonomous portrait drawing at college expo

contentBlocks.content:
Scribblz began as a question: "What if art could happen anywhere, even on the side of a building?" The result is a portable robot that transforms any glass surface into a canvas.

The robot uses a combination of vacuum suction for adhesion and a precision CoreXY motion system for drawing. Users simply upload an image through the companion app, and Scribblz converts it to optimized pen strokes.

items: Dual vacuum system with 50N holding force - works on any smooth glass
200mm x 200mm drawing area with ±0.5mm positioning accuracy
Image-to-path conversion with adjustable detail levels
Battery powered for truly portable operation
Quick-change pen system supporting markers, pens, and paint markers

contentBlocks.content:
The most challenging aspect was ensuring reliable adhesion while maintaining drawing accuracy. Glass surfaces vary widely in texture and cleanliness, so I designed a suction system with real-time pressure monitoring. If adhesion drops below a threshold, the robot pauses and alerts the user.

The CoreXY motion system was chosen for its speed and accuracy. Unlike traditional cartesian systems, CoreXY keeps both motors stationary on the frame, reducing moving mass and enabling faster acceleration without sacrificing precision.
The intersection of robotics and art opens up possibilities we never imagined. Scribblz is just the beginning.
contentBlocks.author: Project Reflection

projects.name: 6-DOF 3D Printed Robotic Arm
projects.description: A fully 3D printed 6 degree-of-freedom articulated robot arm with custom inverse kinematics, trajectory planning, and an intuitive teach-pendant interface for programming movements.
projects.challenge: Create an accessible, low-cost robot arm platform that rivals commercial systems in precision and capability. The design needed to be fully 3D printable, use affordable stepper motors, and include professional-grade motion control software.
projects.solution: Designed a modular joint system where each joint is a self-contained unit with integrated motor mount, bearing seats, and cable routing. Implemented analytical inverse kinematics for real-time end-effector control. Developed a custom trajectory planner that generates smooth, jerk-limited motion profiles.
projects.impact: The arm achieves 0.3mm repeatability and can lift 500g at full extension. The design has been downloaded over 2,000 times on Printables. Used as a teaching platform in robotics courses at 3 universities.

subsystems.name: Base & J1 Assembly
subsystems.description: Heavy-duty rotating base with integrated electronics bay. Houses the main controller and power distribution.

subsystems.name: Shoulder Joint (J2)
subsystems.description: Primary lifting joint with 2:1 belt reduction for increased torque. Dual bearing support for rigidity.

subsystems.name: Upper Arm Link
subsystems.description: 250mm aluminum extrusion link with internal cable routing and mounting points for J3.

subsystems.name: Elbow Joint (J3)
subsystems.description: Compact elbow joint with belt drive and integrated limit switches.

subsystems.name: Forearm Link
subsystems.description: 200mm link housing wrist motor cables with snap-fit covers for maintenance.

subsystems.name: 3-Axis Wrist (J4-J6)
subsystems.description: Compact spherical wrist providing pitch, roll, and yaw. Uses miniature NEMA 11 steppers.

subsystems.name: Parallel Gripper
subsystems.description: Servo-driven parallel jaw gripper with 50mm stroke and force feedback.

subsystems.name: Motion Controller
subsystems.description: Raspberry Pi 4 with custom HAT featuring 6x TMC2209 stepper drivers.

milestones.name: Kinematic Design
milestones.description: Completed DH parameter optimization and workspace analysis

milestones.name: Mechanical Design
milestones.description: Finished CAD for all joints and links, began printing

milestones.name: Electronics Integration
milestones.description: Designed and assembled custom controller board

milestones.name: Firmware Development
milestones.description: Implemented IK solver and trajectory planner in Python

milestones.name: Documentation & Release
milestones.description: Published design files, BOM, and assembly instructions

contentBlocks.content:
Industrial robot arms cost tens of thousands of dollars and require specialized training. This project aims to democratize robotics by creating a capable arm that anyone with a 3D printer can build for under $300.

Every structural component is 3D printable in PLA or PETG. The electronics use readily available hobby components. The software runs on a Raspberry Pi with a web-based interface.

items: Payload: 500g at full extension, 1kg at half reach

contentBlocks.content:
The arm uses an analytical IK solver that computes joint angles in under 100 microseconds. This enables real-time end-effector control where the user specifies the desired gripper position and orientation, and the software instantly calculates how to move each joint.

The solver handles all 8 possible IK solutions and automatically selects the one closest to the current configuration, ensuring smooth motion without unexpected flips.

Smooth motion is critical for precision tasks. The trajectory planner generates S-curve velocity profiles that limit jerk (rate of acceleration change), resulting in vibration-free movement. The planner also performs collision checking against a simplified self-model to prevent the arm from hitting itself.

projects.name: Custom Carbon Fiber FPV Drone Frame
projects.description: A custom-designed 5-inch FPV racing drone frame CNC cut from 3K carbon fiber. Optimized for durability, low weight, and easy maintenance through careful topology optimization and modular design.
projects.challenge: Design a competitive FPV drone frame that improves upon commercial offerings in terms of crash durability, vibration damping, and component accessibility. The frame needed to survive high-speed crashes while protecting expensive electronics.
projects.solution: Used topology optimization to identify stress concentrations and reinforce critical areas while removing unnecessary material. Implemented a true-X geometry for predictable handling. Designed a floating camera mount system that isolates the HD camera from motor vibrations.
projects.impact: The frame weighs only 85g while surviving multiple 60mph crashes. The vibration isolation system reduced jello in HD footage by 80% compared to hard-mounted cameras. Design files shared with local FPV community.

subsystems.name: Main Bottom Plate
subsystems.description: 2.5mm 3K carbon fiber bottom plate with integrated battery strap slots and motor soft-mounts.

subsystems.name: Top Plate
subsystems.description: 2mm carbon fiber top plate with HD camera mounting points and receiver antenna routing.

subsystems.name: Motor Arms
subsystems.description: 5mm thick removable arms with reinforced motor mounts. True-X geometry for balanced thrust.

children.name: Front Left Arm
children.description: Front left motor arm with 2205 motor mount

children.name: Front Right Arm
children.description: Front right motor arm with 2205 motor mount

children.name: Rear Left Arm
children.description: Rear left motor arm with 2205 motor mount

children.name: Rear Right Arm
children.description: Rear right motor arm with 2205 motor mount

subsystems.name: Floating Camera Mount
subsystems.description: TPU-damped camera mount isolating HD camera from motor vibrations. Adjustable 0-60° tilt.

subsystems.name: Aluminum Standoffs
subsystems.description: 30mm aluminum standoffs with M3 threading. Anodized for corrosion resistance.

subsystems.name: Hardware Kit
subsystems.description: Titanium and steel hardware optimized for strength-to-weight ratio.

milestones.name: Research & Requirements
milestones.description: Analyzed commercial frames and defined performance targets

milestones.name: CAD Design
milestones.description: Completed parametric design in SolidWorks with FEA validation

milestones.name: First Prototype
milestones.description: CNC cut first prototype from 3mm G10 fiberglass for testing

milestones.name: Carbon Fiber Production
milestones.description: Cut final design from 3K carbon fiber sheets

milestones.name: Flight Testing
milestones.description: Completed 50+ flights and multiple crash tests

milestones.name: Design Optimization
milestones.description: Revised arm geometry based on crash data

contentBlocks.content:
After breaking my third commercial frame in a month of racing, I decided to design my own. The goal: create a frame that could survive my crashes while being lighter than anything on the market.

This project combined my love for FPV flying with my engineering skills, resulting in a frame that's been crashed dozens of times and keeps flying.

items: True-X geometry: Equal arm angles for predictable, balanced flight
Replaceable arms: Swap a broken arm in 2 minutes without rebuilding
Topology optimized: Material only where stress analysis shows it's needed
Vibration isolation: Floating camera mount eliminates HD footage jello
Clean stack: 30.5mm mounting pattern fits all modern flight controllers

contentBlocks.content:
The frame is cut from aerospace-grade 3K twill carbon fiber using a CNC router. The 3K weave provides excellent stiffness while the twill pattern resists delamination during crashes.

Cutting carbon requires careful attention to feeds and speeds to avoid delamination. I use a diamond-coated bit at 18,000 RPM with a feed rate of 800mm/min, plus a sacrificial backing board.

The frame has survived impacts that would destroy commercial alternatives. Key to this durability is the arm mounting system: instead of arms being part of the main plate, they bolt on with 4 screws each. This means the arm can flex and absorb impact energy without cracking the main structure.

In 6 months of aggressive flying, I've replaced 2 arms but the main plates are still original.

welcomePageData.name: Liam Carlin
welcomePageData.title: Mechanical Engineering Student
welcomePageData.bio: I am passionate about robotics, mechanical design, and building things that move. I love tackling complex engineering challenges and turning ideas into reality through CAD, prototyping, experimenting, and iteration.
welcomePageData.aboutContent: I built this interactive portfolio to showcase my engineering work in a way that goes beyond traditional resumes and static images. Each project features fully interactive 3D CAD models that you can explore, rotate, and examine in detail—just like reviewing actual designs in a professional CAD environment.
